title: AB 1534
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature in California emphasizes the importance of county assessors following state laws for consistent and accurate property assessments. They aim to protect taxpayers by ensuring that decisions on property exemptions and ownership changes are made by certified staff. The Legislature also intends for education and certification requirements to be implemented efficiently with the help of county assessors and the State Board of Equalization. The Legislature in California emphasizes the importance of county assessors following state laws for property assessments. Implementation of education and certification requirements should be efficient and economical, utilizing existing resources with the advice of the State Board of Equalization. Contracts for appraisal work must be competitively bid and entered into on a fixed fee or hourly rate basis. Contracts for appraisal work in California must be competitively bid and entered into on a fixed fee or hourly rate basis. Contractors must maintain confidentiality of assessee information as required by law. A contractor in California must maintain the confidentiality of assessee information and records obtained during appraisal work. The assessor can request information from the assessee, and the contractor must not provide appraisal data to anyone without authorization. A contractor in California must maintain the confidentiality of assessee information and records obtained during appraisal work. They are not allowed to provide appraisal data to unauthorized parties and must return all assessee records to the assessor within 90 days of contract conclusion. In California, contractors must maintain confidentiality of assessee records obtained during appraisal work, returning them to the assessor within 90 days. Contracts must include provisions from the State Board of Equalization, and contractors are defined as non-state, county, or city employees performing appraisal work. A new section on Assessment Analyst Certificates is added to the Revenue and Taxation Code. In California, contractors performing appraisal work must maintain confidentiality of assessee records and return them to the assessor within 90 days. A new section on Assessment Analyst Certificates in the Revenue and Taxation Code requires assessors to hold a valid certificate for decisions on changes in ownership and property tax exemptions. The board in California contracts with the Department of Human Resources for assessment analyst certificate examinations. Applicants must pass the exam and demonstrate competency in making ownership change or exemption decisions. Denials can be reviewed under the Administrative Procedure Act. Applicants for a certificate in California must demonstrate competency in ownership change or exemption decisions defined by the board's regulations. Denial of a certificate can be reviewed under the Administrative Procedure Act. The board does not charge counties or applicants for examinations or training. Certified assessment analysts must complete 24 hours of board-approved training annually to maintain their certificate, with excess hours carrying over for up to three years. The board requires certified assessment analysts to complete 24 hours of annual training, with excess hours carrying over for up to three years. Failure to comply may result in certificate revocation. Training covers new legal developments, and an advanced certificate is available for experienced applicants. The board offers an advanced assessment analyst certificate for experienced applicants who have completed a prescribed course of study or passed an advanced level examination. To maintain this certificate, holders must complete 12 hours of training annually. The board, with the advice of assessors, prescribes an advanced course of study and exam. Holders of the advanced assessment analyst certificate must complete 12 hours of training annually. Excess training hours can be carried over for up to two years. Failure to comply may result in certificate revocation following the Administrative Procedure Act. The advanced assessment analyst certificate requires completion of annual training on legal developments. Applicants must disclose financial interests in legal entities at certification and annually thereafter. Failure to complete training may lead to certificate revocation under the Administrative Procedure Act. Training for the advanced assessment analyst certificate includes updates on case law, statutory law, and administrative rules. Applicants must disclose financial interests in legal entities at certification and annually thereafter. Compliance with Fair Political Practices Commission filing requirements may fulfill this disclosure obligation. The board may issue a temporary certificate to newly elected or appointed assessors or new employees in the county assessor's office for up to one year to allow them to take an examination for certification. Temporary certificates cannot be renewed. The board may issue an interim certificate to current assessors or county assessor office employees for up to four years to allow them to take an examination for certification. Noncertificated staff can assist with exemption applications and ownership documents but cannot make decisions. This article allows assessors to efficiently manage staff resources, with noncertificated staff assisting in preparing exemption applications and ownership documents but not making decisions. It applies only in counties that have passed a resolution requiring certification.
